Based on a backward‐induction analysis of the 12–round negotiation (with money “depreciating” each round by 10% for you and 20% for Bob), an equilibrium proposal in round 1 would roughly be to offer Bob $38.55 and keep $61.45 for yourself. (In outline, we work backward: in the final round Bob—having the “last–diminished” bargaining power—can extract nearly all the value for himself; then in round 11 you must offer him enough so his immediate share (discounted at 0.8^(10)) is at least what he’d get in round 12; and so on back to round 1. Under typical “subgame–perfect” reasoning, the numbers work out approximately as follows.)

Thus, as Alice in round 1 you can propose:

{"alice_gain": 61.45, "bob_gain": 38.55}

(Note: The exact numbers can depend on the limit‐approach to “infinitely small” offers at the very end. For our purposes these rounded figures capture the idea.)
